Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Ecologies of Water Governance

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Water scarcity has been widely linked to political and economic instability. As new methods for water extraction, delivery, and management are explored and implemented, evaluating the efficacy and effectiveness of water governance structures becomes critical to preventing water stress. This project, which trains a graduate student in how to conduct rigorous, empirically-grounded scientific fieldwork, explores how water governance unfolds on the ground, through formal and informal means, under conditions of increasing resource scarcity and growing population sizes. The lessons this research produces can be of value in deepening understanding of similar situations, especially in economies where agriculture is irrigation-dependent and where water access is stressed between the demands of a large urban population and the demands of an extensive irrigation-dependent agricultural sector.

Maira Hayat, under the supervision of Dr. William Mazzarella of the University of Chicago, will explore water governance focusing on two locales: the drinking water market in an urban setting, and the public canal irrigation network in a village context. The research will take place in Pakistan, home to the world's largest contiguous irrigation network fed by the river Indus and its tributaries. Concentrated in the Punjab province, this network has roots in 19th century colonial policies aiming, in parallel, at increasing tax revenue from agricultural production, and 'settling' the region by converting the predominantly nomadic locals to sedentary agriculturalists. This research will deepen understanding of the relation between law and political economy; bureaucracies, markets and the intersection of knowledge and value regimes; and resource governance worldwide. It will contribute to analyses of law and economic life through charting the relation between economy and sovereignty, and contemporary water governance. This research will further understanding of the successes and failures of public irrigation, and enable policymakers to design better-informed policy, and help make policy less top-down at a time of extensive water-sector reform in many water-stressed contexts. This research combines fieldwork, interviews, focus groups, archival research, collection of oral histories, and legal textual analysis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Through examination of irrigation water distribution mechanisms and disputes; legal regimes, loopholes and illegal but illicit rural irrigation water distribution practices; private sector water management practices; and the development sector’s discourse and practice around irrigation reform, this research project deepens understandings of public bureaucracies and their perceptions, state performance and the micro dynamics of service delivery, and agricultural water-use practices in the Indus basin – the largest contiguous irrigation network in the world, concentrated in Pakistan. Employing a mixed methods approach – heavy reliance on qualitative research spread out over fifteen months of field research Pakistan’s Punjab province – that entailed interviewing, participant observation in offices at seminars, conferences, meetings, adhoc as well as routine official committee proceedings, oral history collection, village tours and inspections of water infrastructure with Irrigation personnel, archival research and newspaper and other media analysis, this project provides insight into the contemporary water crisis in Pakistan that goes beyond predominant ‘thin’ renditions of the crisis, and towards a deeper, richer, historicized understanding.   

Intellectual merit: This research brings together literature on bureaucracies and administration with literature on the state in political anthropology. By combining research in public and private bureaucracies, it breaks down traditional silos in scholarship. Different from the familiar anthropological view on disaggregated states (pace Radcliffe-Brown and Philip Abrams), it urges a turn to taking seriously state failure in its local, emic understandings: who does the state fail and how? How can a bureaucrat be failed by the state he/she works as part of? Rather than consider bureaucracies in terms of the violence they un/intentionally wield, as recent influential analyses have (Gupta 2012; Graeber 2015), this research views bureaucracy as work and its devaluation to labor (diharrii; Urdu for labor/daily wage) as corruption. It also views corruption – a topic attracting increasing comment in anthropology (Shah 2009; Anjaria 2011; Das 2015) – in a new light by seeing it as a way of (tentatively, awkwardly) inhabiting the everyday. Building upon extended fieldwork with a female Irrigation official – the first-ever and only female officer of that rank in the Irrigation department – the research sensitizes us to the implicit assumption of a male subject of the everyday. It unpacks ‘the bureaucratic’ and ‘the everyday’ in their gendered specifity.

Broader impact: This research constitutes the first extended analysis of (i) recorded case law archives on irrigation water disputes in the Punjab province and (ii) water disputes as they unfolded during the co-PI’s fieldwork. It deepens understanding of the successes and failures of public irrigation, and consequently, enables policymakers to design better-informed policy, and help make policy less top-down at a time of extensive water-sector reform in Pakistan. The focus group discussions that were a part of this project’s methodology, make lower-level Irrigation officials’ voices heard and upon compilation as a report to be submitted to the department, promise to effect change in policy. The co-PI will disseminate the results of this research at workshops and lectures organized at the Irrigation department, local universities and NGOs. The co-PI will also mentor students at local universities and write in local Urdu and English newspapers to engage a broader audience in the conversation on water-sector reform in the country. This research also involved an ethnography of a water multinational corporation’s operations in Pakistan – this “studying up” (Nader 1972) will enhance understandings of powerful structures, indicate how they can be made more equitable and accountable to the public weal.
